title: Implement AOT compilation for Maggie bytecode
description:
Compile Maggie bytecode to native code ahead-of-time, eliminating interpreter overhead.

Approach options:
1. Generate Go code from bytecode → compile with `go build` (simplest)
2. Generate LLVM IR → use LLVM backend
3. Generate native assembly directly (most complex)

Recommended: Option 1 (Go codegen) - leverage existing Go toolchain.

For each bytecode method, generate a Go function that performs the same operations directly. The generated code would look like:

```go
func CompiledMethod_Lexer_nextToken(vm *VM, self Value, args []Value) Value {
    // Direct Go code instead of bytecode interpretation
    temp0 := self.GetIvar(0)  // instead of PUSH_IVAR 0
    temp1 := vm.Send(temp0, "peek", nil)  // instead of SEND
    // ...
}
```

Benefits:
- No interpreter dispatch overhead
- Go compiler optimizes the generated code
- Native performance for compiled methods

Deliverables:
- BytecodeToGo translator
- Integration with build process
- Benchmark showing speedup
close_reason: Implemented AOT compiler with bytecode-to-Go translation, VM integration, and benchmarks

title: Implement primitiveSelect using reflect.Select
description: Implement Channel class>>select:ifNone: primitive using reflect.Select to wait on multiple channels simultaneously.
close_reason: Implemented Channel select: and select:ifNone: with tests and examples

title: Phase 4: Self-Hosting Compiler (Epic)
description: Write Maggie compiler in Maggie itself. Keep Go compiler for AOT compilation. Bootstrap: compile Maggie compiler with Go compiler, then compile compiler with itself.
close_reason: Duplicate epic - using maggie-8rg instead

title: Lexer: tokenize operators and punctuation
description: Handle binary selectors (+, -, *, /, <, >, =, ~, etc.) and punctuation (., ;, ^, |, :=, [, ], (, ), {, }). Test: (Lexer on: '+ := [ ]') allTokens size = 5
close_reason: Implemented in lib/compiler/Lexer.mag

title: Bug: OpStoreGlobal does nothing
description: OpStoreGlobal is parsed but does nothing - value stays on stack, no actual store happens. Location: vm/interpreter.go lines 383-388. The opcode handler needs to actually store the value to the global.
close_reason: Fixed: OpStoreGlobal now stores values to i.Globals[name]

title: Implement JIT compilation
description: Low priority future recommendation: The bytecode design would support JIT compilation. This could significantly improve performance for hot paths. Consider profile-guided optimization to inline frequently-called primitives.
close_reason: Replaced with detailed JIT epic maggie-c2y

title: Add dedicated AST nodes for nil/true/false literals
description: Quick win: Replace parseNil() returning *Variable with parseNilLiteral() returning *NilLiteral (and same for true/false). Currently nil, true, false are treated as variables during parsing and must be special-cased during codegen. Location: compiler/parser.go lines 760-776.
close_reason: Implemented with tests

title: Implement vm/context.go
description: Create ContextObject wrapping context.Context. Implement primitives: withTimeout:, withCancel, isCancelled, cancel, deadline.

title: Implement ImageReader (load VM state from binary)
description: Deserialize binary image: read header, tables, classes, methods, objects, globals. Reconstruct VTables and object graph.
close_reason: Implemented with tests, all passing

title: Implement become: for object identity swapping
description: Implement become: which swaps the identity of two objects (all references to A now point to B and vice versa). Central to Smalltalk for: proxies, lazy loading, schema migration, live updates. HIGH COMPLEXITY: In Go's memory model, requires either object table indirection or full heap scan. Consider oneWayBecome: as simpler alternative.
close_reason: Implemented become: with two approaches: (1) become: swaps object contents for two-way identity swap, (2) becomeForward: sets up forwarding pointer for one-way redirection. ObjectFromValue automatically follows forwarding chains.

title: Implement Inspector development tool
description: Object inspector: display object class, instance variables, slot values. Navigate object graph. Support for all value types (SmallInt, Float, Symbol, Object).

Should properly traverse object hierarchy for drill-down.

title: Create JIT controller for hot method compilation
description: Background goroutine that compiles hot methods using existing AOT compiler. Queue-based async compilation. Write generated Go to files. Files: vm/jit.go
close_reason: Implemented JIT controller with background compilation worker. 120 hot methods compiled during Maggie compiler execution.

title: Add stack bounds checking with dynamic growth
description: Quick win: The interpreter uses fixed-size stacks (stack: make([]Value, 1024), frames: make([]*CallFrame, 256)) with no dynamic growth - will panic on overflow. Add bounds checking to push() that grows the stack when needed: if i.sp >= len(i.stack) { i.stack = append(i.stack, make([]Value, 1024)...) }. Location: vm/interpreter.go lines 75-78.
close_reason: Implemented with tests

title: Fix memory leaks in VM (keepAlive, blockRegistry, GC)
description: Multiple memory management issues: 1) keepAlive slice in vm/vm.go:53 grows unboundedly - objects added but never removed. 2) blockRegistry map in interpreter.go:1171-1173 never releases blocks. 3) No proper GC integration - the pointer-to-Object stored in NaN-boxed values won't be traced by Go's GC unless there's a root reference. Options: use Go's GC by making all objects referenced from a root set, implement simple mark-sweep collector, or at minimum fix the leaks.
close_reason: Fixed: keepAlive now uses map with mark-sweep GC; blockRegistry cleanup via releaseBlocksForFrame

title: Implement CompiledMethod structure
description: Implement CompiledMethod struct: selector, class, arity, numTemps, literals array, bytecode, nested BlockMethods. Include SourceMap for debugging (bytecode offset to line/column).
close_reason: Implemented CompiledMethod and BlockMethod with builders, source mapping, and 25+ tests

title: Phase 1: Minimal VM

title: Maggie compiler: implement block variable captures
description:
The Maggie self-hosting compiler (BytecodeGenerator.mag) doesn't implement variable captures for blocks. When a block accesses variables from the enclosing method scope (e.g., [i := i + 1] in a whileTrue: loop), the block can't find those variables and falls back to treating them as globals.

The TODO in visitBlockNode: says 'Handle captures properly'. Need to:
1. Track outer scope temps when compiling nested blocks
2. Use OpPushHomeTemp/OpStoreHomeTemp for method-level temp access from blocks
3. Or implement proper capture mechanism with OpCaptureTemp

This causes whileTrue: loops with variable updates to fail - the loop runs but variable updates don't persist.
close_reason: Fixed by moving selector to method scope and fixing Go compiler's STORE_CAPTURED handling

title: Implement Token class in Maggie

close_reason: Self-compile tests all pass. The Maggie compiler (compiled by Go) successfully compiles its own source files. 28 Token.mag methods compile with both compilers. Execution equivalence tests pass including loops and factorial.

title: Implement mutable cells for block variable captures
description:
Maggie currently captures block variables by value, not by reference. This breaks standard Smalltalk semantics where mutations to captured variables should be visible in the outer scope.

Example that fails:
```smalltalk
| x |
x := 10.
[x := x + 1] value.
x   "Should be 11, but is 10"
```

Nested block example:
```smalltalk
(test) ifTrue: [
    | count |
    count := 0.
    [count < 3] whileTrue: [count := count + 1].
    ^count   "Should be 3, returns 0"
]
```

Fix requires:
1. Compiler detects variables that are both captured AND assigned
2. Those variables get allocated in heap cells (boxed)
3. All access goes through cell indirection
4. Both Go and Maggie compilers need updating

Current workaround: declare variables at method scope instead of block scope (uses HOME_TEMP opcodes).
close_reason: Implemented mutable cells for block variable captures. Added Cell type to vm/value.go with cellRegistry to prevent GC. Added MAKE_CELL/CELL_GET/CELL_SET opcodes. Updated Go compiler with findCellVariables analysis. Added tests. Maggie compiler has opcode definitions (full analysis TODO).

title: Create test harness for bytecode execution
description: Build a test harness that can construct bytecode directly in Go and execute it. This enables testing the interpreter without needing a parser/compiler. Include helpers for common patterns.
close_reason: Implemented via CompiledMethodBuilder in compiled_method.go and BytecodeBuilder in bytecode.go. Tests in interpreter_test.go and vm_test.go demonstrate direct bytecode construction and execution.

title: Design review: Non-local returns via panic/recover
description: Questionable design: Non-local returns use panic/recover (interpreter.go lines 229-254, 827-832). While this works, it's slower than a proper return stack and makes debugging difficult. Consider implementing a proper return stack mechanism.
close_reason:
Design Review Complete.

**Current Design Analysis:**
Non-local returns use Go's panic/recover mechanism (interpreter.go:267-297, 974-980):
- NonLocalReturn struct carries the return value and target frame
- Execute() sets up defer with recover to catch non-local returns
- Block return panics with NonLocalReturn, caught by the home method's defer

**Trade-offs:**

Pros of panic/recover approach:
1. **Simplicity**: Leverages Go's existing stack unwinding
2. **Correctness**: Automatically handles arbitrary nesting depth
3. **Interop**: Works correctly across Go/Maggie boundaries (primitives can call blocks)
4. **Safety**: Properly validates home frame is still valid before returning

Cons:
1. **Performance**: panic/recover is ~100-500ns overhead per non-local return
2. **Debugging**: Go stack traces include panic machinery, can be confusing
3. **Profiling**: pprof may show misleading hotspots in recover handlers

**Alternative: Explicit return stack**
A return stack approach would:
- Maintain an explicit "return target" stack alongside the call stack
- Check return targets after each block evaluation
- Avoid panic/recover overhead

**Recommendation: Keep current design**

Reasons:
1. Non-local returns are relatively rare (only explicit ^ in blocks)
2. The 100-500ns overhead is negligible compared to interpreter dispatch
3. Correctness and simplicity outweigh micro-optimization
4. A return stack would add complexity to every block invocation path

**When to reconsider**: If profiling shows non-local return as a hotspot (unlikely), or if implementing a tracing JIT where panic/recover would interfere with optimization.

The current implementation is well-designed with proper goroutine boundary checking and frame validity validation.

title: Design review: Symbol tags for string/dictionary encoding
description: Questionable design: String, Dictionary, GrpcClient, GrpcStream, Result are all encoded using the symbol tag, requiring cascading checks in vtableFor() (lines 1059-1146 in interpreter.go). Consider using object pointers instead to simplify dispatch logic.
close_reason:
Design Review Complete.

**Current Design Analysis:**
The vtableFor() function (interpreter.go:870-958) uses cascading type checks on symbol-tagged values:
- IsStringValue(v) → String
- IsDictionaryValue(v) → Dictionary  
- isGrpcClientValue(v) → GrpcClient
- isGrpcStreamValue(v) → GrpcStream
- isResultValue(v) → Success/Failure

**Trade-offs:**
1. **Memory efficiency**: Symbol-tagging avoids heap allocation for these values, keeping them as 64-bit NaN-boxed values
2. **Performance cost**: Every dispatch requires cascading type checks (O(n) where n = number of symbol-encoded types)
3. **Complexity**: Adding new symbol-encoded types requires updating multiple dispatch sites

**Recommendation: Keep current design with minor optimization**

Reasons:
1. The types being encoded (strings, dictionaries) are frequently created and benefit from avoiding heap allocation
2. The cascading checks are O(1) in practice (constant number of types)
3. Converting to object pointers would require heap allocation for every string/dictionary creation

**Suggested optimization**: Create a type-tag lookup table at VM init that maps high symbol IDs to vtables, replacing cascading if-else with a single table lookup:

```go
func (i *Interpreter) vtableFor(v Value) *VTable {
    if v.IsSymbol() {
        id := v.SymbolID()
        if vt := i.symbolTypeVTables[id>>48]; vt != nil {
            return vt
        }
    }
    // ... rest of dispatch
}
```

This would be a medium-priority optimization if profiling shows vtableFor as a hotspot.

close_reason: Created lib/WaitGroup.mag and lib/Semaphore.mag with convenience methods

title: AST: Implement BlockNode class
description: Create BlockNode for block literals. Fields: parameters, temporaries, statements. Methods: parameters, temporaries, statements, arity, accept:. Test: (BlockNode parameters: #(x y) temporaries: #() statements: stmts)
close_reason: Implemented

title: Implement monomorphic inline cache
description: Add single-entry inline cache at each call site. Cache (class, method) pair on first call, check before vtable lookup. Expected ~90% hit rate based on Cog VM data. Files: vm/inline_cache.go, vm/interpreter.go
close_reason: Implemented monomorphic and polymorphic inline caching with 87.6% monomorphic rate and 99.82% hit rate

title: Create initial development image
description: Bootstrap image with core classes compiled from source: Object, Boolean, SmallInteger, Float, String, Symbol, Array, Block, Channel, Process, Result.
close_reason: Bootstrap tool compiles 167 methods from 16 .mag source files. Image load/save working correctly.

title: Fix block registry memory leak
description: Quick win: Add releaseBlock(id int) method to Interpreter that calls delete(blockRegistry, id). Call this when a block's home frame is popped. Location: vm/interpreter.go lines 1171-1173. The global blockRegistry map currently never removes blocks, causing unbounded memory growth.
close_reason: Implemented with tests

title: Implement compiled code persistence
description: Generate Go package with all hot methods for next startup. Similar to Sista persisting to snapshots. Files: vm/jit_loader.go. Options: compiled into binary (MVP) or Go plugin loading (advanced).
close_reason: Implemented all three persistence modes: static build, plugin loading, and image persistence with gzip compression

title: Make Cell type thread-safe
description: Cell struct needs sync.RWMutex or atomic.Value for thread-safe Get/Set operations when cells are shared across goroutines via forked blocks.
close_reason: Added sync.RWMutex to Cell struct. CellGet uses RLock, CellSet uses Lock for thread-safe access.

title: Register MutexClass in VM bootstrap
description: Add vm.MutexClass to VM struct, create class in bootstrap, register in Globals.
close_reason: Added MutexClass to VM struct, created class in bootstrap, registered in Globals, added isMutexValue check in ClassFor, called registerMutexPrimitives

title: Implement thisContext execution
description: Execute OpPushContext bytecode to create activation context objects. Currently the opcode exists but interpreter doesn't handle it. Needed for: debuggers, stack traces, proper exception handling, continuations. Requires: Context class with sender/receiver/method/args/temps slots, interpreter changes to instantiate it.
close_reason: Implemented thisContext with full support for interpreter, AOT, and JIT modes

title: Phase 4: Add WaitGroup and Semaphore Classes
description: Implement WaitGroup (wrapping sync.WaitGroup) and Semaphore (using buffered channel) classes. Week 4 of concurrency overhaul.
close_reason: Phase 4 complete: WaitGroup and Semaphore implemented with comprehensive tests

title: Add synchronization to cellRegistry
description: cellRegistry has no mutex protection. Add sync.RWMutex for thread-safe access.
close_reason: Added sync.Mutex to cellRegistry. NewCell now locks before adding to registry.

title: Benchmark: Primitive arithmetic operations
description: Benchmark SmallInteger and Float primitives: +, -, *, /, comparisons. Compare with native Go operations to measure overhead.
close_reason: Benchmarks implemented in vm/benchmark_test.go

title: Define AST node types
description: Define AST node types: LiteralNode (int, float, string, symbol, array), VariableNode, AssignmentNode, MessageNode, CascadeNode, BlockNode, MethodNode, ClassNode, ReturnNode. Include source locations for error reporting.
close_reason: Defined AST node types in compiler/ast.go: Position, Span, Node interface, expression nodes (IntLiteral, FloatLiteral, StringLiteral, SymbolLiteral, CharLiteral, ArrayLiteral, DynamicArray, Variable, Assignment, UnaryMessage, BinaryMessage, KeywordMessage, Cascade, Block, Self, Super, ThisContext), statement nodes (ExprStmt, Return), definition nodes (MethodDef, ClassDef, NamespaceDecl, ImportDecl, SourceFile).

title: Phase 5-6: Memory Management for Concurrency Objects
description: Move registries to VM struct, integrate cleanup with GC, implement finalizers. Weeks 5-6 of concurrency overhaul. Higher risk - timing sensitive.
close_reason: Phase 5-6 complete: ConcurrencyRegistry on VM, sweep methods for channels/processes/blocks, VM isolation, memory leak tests

title: Phase 7: Add Channel Select Statement
description: Implement Channel select: and select:ifNone: using reflect.Select for waiting on multiple channels. Week 7 of concurrency overhaul.
close_reason: Phase 7 complete: Channel select: and select:ifNone: implemented using reflect.Select
